Authors:
Shu-Yan Liu, Dan-Ni Jin, Monika Götz, Michael Bradshaw,
Miao Liu, Susumu Takamatsu, Uwe Braun
Title:
Phylogeny and taxonomy of Podosphaera filipendulae
revisited
Keywords:
Erysiphaceae, molecular phylogeny, Podosphaera spiraeae,
P. filipendulensis, powdery mildew
Abstract:
The phylogeny and taxonomy of Podosphaera filipendulae
have been examined on the basis of a broader sampling, also in relation
to P. spiraeae, including sequences retrieved from Asian, European and
North American collections. The results confirmed P. filipendulae and P.
spiraeae as two separate species, although they are morphologically
barely distinguishable, which is in line with the phylogeny of the host
genera. Filipendula pertains to Rosaceae subfamily Rosoideae and Spiraea
to subfamily Amygdaloideae (previously Spiraeoideae). Seven sequences of
P. spiraeae obtained from Asian, North and South American collections on
Aruncus dioicus and Spiraea spp. form a separate well-supported clade.
Although ITS sequences retrieved from Asian, European and North American
specimens of P. filipendulae on various Filipendula spp. are identical
to the sequences gained from P. macularis on hop, there is one base
substitution at the 5’-end of 28S rRNA gene between the species. This
result is in line with the evidence that the hop powdery mildew and P.
filipendulae are biologically and morphologically clearly distinguished,
which is in favour of maintaining two separate species. The recently
described P. filipendulensis is reduced to synonymy with P.
filipendulae. The ex-holotype sequence of P. filipendulensis is 100 %
identical with all other P. filipendulae sequences, and the postulated
“morphological differences” are within the variability of the latter
species.
